user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(uint32 ModeBits)
{
    char param[32];

    if (OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.EnableTermControl)
    {
        if (ModeBits == OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("sgr0", NULL);
        }
        else
        {
            if ((ModeBits & OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT) == 0)
            {
                /* no highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("rmso", NULL);
            }
            else
            {
                /* set highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("smso", NULL);
            }

            snprintf(param, sizeof(param), "%d", OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(ModeBits));
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("setaf", param);
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL 0x0
...
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT 0x8
...
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(x) ((x)&0x07)
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobalData_t OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The only function parameter is ModeBits and it is only read (used in comparisons, bitwise & and passed to a macro) — there are no assignments to ModeBits. The macro OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(x) expands to a bitwise expression ((x) & 0x07) and does not modify its argument. The local array param is a local object (not a function parameter) and is written via snprintf, which is permitted. Calls to OS_BSP_ExecTput pass string literals, NULL, or the local param; there are no pointer parameters of this function that are being reassigned. Therefore there is no evidence in this function of violating MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (no function parameter is modified).
